post_title: Researchers set new efficiency record for stable binary organic solar cells
title: Highly efficient and stable binary OSCs with a record PCE of 19.70%
post_content:
Introduction:

Organic solar cells (OSCs) are a promising alternative to traditional silicon-based solar panels due to their lightweight, flexible, and translucent nature. The development of new materials and optimization of the fabrication process have led to a rapid improvement in the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of OSCs, which has surpassed 19%. However, achieving a balance between efficiency and stability in conventional OSCs remains a challenge.

In this article, we will explore the work of a research group led by Prof. Ge Ziyi from the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering (NIMTE) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, who have developed two self-assembled molecules (SAMs) with large dipole moments and employed them as hole-transporting layers (HTLs) in binary OSCs, achieving highly efficient and stable binary OSCs with a record PCE of up to 19.70%.

Body:

Organic solar cells (OSCs) have attracted great attention in the field of organic electronic devices due to their advantages of light weight, good mechanical flexibility and translucency. The development of new materials and optimization of the fabrication process have contributed to the rapid improvement in the PCE of OSCs, which has exceeded 19%. However, achieving a balance between efficiency and stability in conventional OSCs still remains a challenge.

To address this issue, researchers at NIMTE designed and synthesized two asymmetric SAMs with asymmetric backbone, namely BrCz and BrBACz. The two SAMs served as HTLs in binary OSCs based on the well-known system of PM6:Y6, PM6:eC9, PM6:L8-BO, and D18:eC9, respectively.

Compared with conventional PEDOT:PSS-controlled OSCs, the BrCz-controlled and BrBACz-controlled OSCs exhibited higher transmittance, deeper work function, and lower surface energy, thus realizing enhanced hole extraction, increased hole mobility, decreased interface resistance, and reduced carrier recombination.

The BrBACz-based OSC achieved a record high PCE of 19.70% with a remarkable current density of 29.20 mA cm-2 and a circuit voltage of 0.856 V, which is the highest value reported to date for binary OSCs. When exposed to ambient air (40 ± 5% humidity) and continuous illumination for 1,036 hours, the BrBACz-controlled device can maintain up to 95.0% of its initial efficiency, which is the best air stability for the conventional OSCs.

In addition, the BrBACz-controlled device also plays a remarkable role in other well-known binary systems, such as PM6:Y6, PM6:L8-BO and D18:eC9, demonstrating its excellent generality.

Conclusion:

This work may shed light on the future development and application of highly efficient and stable OSCs through rational molecular structure design. However, achieving a balance between efficiency and stability in conventional OSCs still remains a challenge. Their work highlights the importance of molecular structure design in the development of highly efficient and stable OSCs and serves as a valuable reference for future research in this field.

Title: Unleashing the Power of Voices: A Look into OpenAI's Voice Engine and Its Potential Impact

Introduction

In the ever-evolving world of artificial intelligence (AI), OpenAI continues to push boundaries and innovate. With groundbreaking technologies like ChatGPT and the recently revealed Sora, a text-to-video generator, OpenAI maintains its position at the forefront of AI development. Recently, the company shared details about its latest venture – Voice Engine, an advanced voice cloning AI model. This blog post explores OpenAI's Voice Engine, its remarkable capabilities, associated risks, and potential applications.

Voice Engine: A Glimpse into the Future

At a small-scale preview, OpenAI introduced Voice Engine, an AI model that generates lifelike, expressive voices based on text inputs and a brief 15-second audio sample. As demonstrated in the provided clip, this technology creates astonishingly authentic-sounding voices, raising questions about potential implications.

Understanding the Risks and Safeguarding Measures

Recognizing the dangers inherent in voice cloning technology, particularly during an election year, OpenAI has been cautious in its approach to Voice Engine. Despite initial development in late 2022, the company has yet to release the model publicly. In a statement, OpenAI acknowledged the risks and outlined measures put in place to mitigate misuse:

 Usage policies restricting impersonation of individuals or organizations without proper consent
 Disclosure requirements when deploying AI-generated voices
 Watermarking to trace generated voices back to Voice Engine
 Monitoring of model usage
 Prohibition against creating one's voices

Private Testing and Real-World Applications

To better understand Voice Engine's potential uses and limitations, OpenAI began private testing with select partners in 2023 under strict guidelines. These early adopters focused on building constructive applications, illustrating the technology's promise while minimizing risks. Examples of these projects include:

 Age of Learning, an edtech startup, leveraged Voice Engine to assist non-readers and young students through pre-scripted voice-overs and tailored replies.
 AI avatar-creating firm HeyGen harnessed the power of Voice Engine to develop a multilingual translation tool, converting speakers' voices across various languages.

Navigating the Public Domain

Though OpenAI keeps Voice Engine in preview mode, comparable alternatives are accessible to the public. One notable example is ElevenLabs, a startup offering an AI-driven voice generation platform. While ElevenLabs boasts several innovative applications, it also faces criticism due to misleading voice simulations—most notably, a deepfake robocall attributed to President Joe Biden encouraging voters to abstain from voting.

Conclusion

Artificial Intelligence holds immense potential, revolutionizing industries and daily life alike. However, responsible innovation requires careful consideration of ethical concerns and possible ramifications. By exploring voice cloning technology like Voice Engine, we gain valuable insights into both its transformative possibilities and underlying challenges. Emphasizing transparency, verification, and thoughtful implementation will ensure that AI advances benefit society while respecting privacy and security.

Introduction

In our technology-driven world, the demand for efficient, cost-effective, and eco-friendly electrical power converters is higher than ever. These converters, which are essential components in various devices such as solar panels, medical equipment, and electric vehicles, have traditionally faced challenges in balancing high-frequency operation, reduced size, and minimized electromagnetic noise. The Challenge: High-Frequency Switching and Electromagnetic Noise

Boost converters are integral components in many electronic devices, converting low-voltage direct current (DC) input into high-voltage DC output. The key to a high-performing boost converter is high-frequency switching, which allows for smaller components and a more compact device. However, faster switching also increases electromagnetic noise and heat production, negatively impacting the converter's performance.

The Kobe University Solution: Resonant Tank Circuits and Soft Switching

Dr. Mishima's team has developed a DC voltage boost converter that successfully combines high-frequency switching with a technique called "soft switching." This technique ensures that the switch transitions occur at zero voltage, significantly minimizing heat loss and reducing electromagnetic noise. Traditionally, soft switching has been achieved using "snubbers," components that offer alternative energy sinks during the transition period, leading to energy losses. The Kobe University researchers, however, have utilized "resonant tank" circuits that store energy during the switching period, resulting in much lower losses.

Title: Introducing the Terraformer: A Revolutionary Approach to Synthetic Natural Gas Production

Introduction

Our planet's reliance on hydrocarbon resources such as crude oil and natural gas presents us with challenges related to extraction difficulties, finitude, and increased atmospheric carbon dioxide levels. In response to these concerns, innovative companies are developing alternative methods to create hydrocarbons sustainably. Among these pioneering firms is Terraform Industries, whose novel invention – the Terraformer – promises to revolutionize how we generate synthetic natural gas through electrical power and air conversion. This article introduces Terraform Industries' newly commissioned demonstrator Terraformer capable of producing synthetic natural gas for the first time.

Understanding the Terraformer System

Approximately equivalent to the dimensions of two shipping containers, the Terraformer comprises three primary components:

1. An electrolyzer, responsible for converting solar power into hydrogen
2. A direct air capture mechanism that isolates CO2 from ambient air
3. A chemical reactor that combines both inputs to yield pipeline-quality synthetic natural gas

Each component operates seamlessly with a single-megawatt solar panel installation, forming a comprehensive and inventive system. While individual elements may draw upon established principles from prior centuries, the integration of these parts yields a completely original approach.

Innovation Through Integration

CEO Casey Handmer acknowledges that the underlying concepts aren't necessarily "super original." Nevertheless, Terraform Industries brings innovation by integrating these ideas into a unique system, incorporating proprietary direct air capture technology, and designing everything around fluctuating solar power input. Consequently, although each part builds on historical precedents, combining them results in an unprecedented methodology.

Cost Reduction Breakthroughs

By leveraging cutting-edge techniques, Terraform Industries reports impressive cost savings. Their system produces hydrogen at below $2.50 per kilogram—well under current market rates ranging between $5-11 per kilogram. Moreover, Terraform Industries claims its direct air capture unit removes CO2 at less than $250 per metric tonne, significantly cheaper than prevailing costs. These advancements pave the way toward competitive pricing for synthetic natural gas compared to traditionally procured LNG.

Achieving Cost Parity

To attain price equilibrium between synthetic natural gas and conventional sources, Terraform Industries aims to reduce expenses further. Improvements include expanding access to affordable solar power installations and manufacturing thousands of Terraformers annually. By doing so, the firm envisions realizing a paradigm shift in global energy infrastructure.

Capitalizing on Capitalism

Handmer recognizes the necessity of constructing a solid business foundation for Terraform Industries amidst noble environmental goals. As he puts it, scaling technologies requires financial viability rather than depleting funds. To remain economically sustainable, Terraform must continually demonstrate profit potential, thereby attracting capital investment and fostering growth.

Realizing Commercial Potential

Although Burbank, California-based Terraform Industries currently supplies limited quantities of natural gas to two anonymous utility providers, early sales represent significant progress. According to Handmer, successful delivery indicates that Terraform-produced gas aligns with industry quality standards. Additionally, the firm explores opportunities involving standalone electrolyzer devices, fabricating various liquid fuels, and accepting preorders for upcoming Terraformer units. Ultimately, Terraform Industries strives to expand factory capabilities to accommodate mass production required to instigate substantial transformation across worldwide energy networks.

post_title: Are high-purity cathode materials truly necessary? An alternative to reduce secondary battery costs
title: Low-purity lithium for secondary batteries: Cutting costs and emissions
post_content:
Battery purity standards have long been a mystery in the secondary battery industry, with manufacturers insisting on strict specifications from cathode material suppliers to maintain consistent quality output. However, a new study by a team of researchers from Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH) has revealed that the purity standards set by cell manufacturers may be too stringent, potentially leading to higher battery production costs and carbon emissions.

In their research, the team led by Professor Yong-Tae Kim from the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at POSTECH, in collaboration with Professor Kyu-Young Park from the Graduate Institute of Ferrous & Eco Materials Technology and the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at POSTECH, and the research team of Dr. Woochul Jung from the Research Institute of Industrial Science and Technology (RIST), found that the presence of approximately 1% magnesium impurity in lithium raw material enhances process efficiency and prolongs the lifespan of secondary batteries.

Traditionally, it is believed that impurities in lithium materials hamper battery performance. Therefore, the goal is to manufacture lithium materials with a purity of at least 99.5%. However, the team's findings suggest that low-purity lithium, not entirely rid of impurities, could reduce secondary battery production costs and carbon dioxide emissions by up to 19.4% and 9.0%, respectively.

The researchers argue that secondary battery cell manufacturers need to reevaluate their current cathode material specifications and consider unconventional approaches to offer a fresh strategy against China's aggressively low prices.

The study's findings are published in the journal Nature Communications.

In this article, we will delve into the impact of lithium raw material purity on the production and performance of secondary battery cathode materials. We will explore the conventional belief that impurities in lithium materials hamper battery performance and examine the research findings that suggest the presence of magnesium impurity in lithium raw material enhances process efficiency and prolongs the lifespan of secondary batteries.

We will also discuss the trade secrets surrounding the purity specifications for cathode materials and how they have led to higher battery production costs. We will examine the research by the team from POSTECH and their findings that low-purity lithium could reduce secondary battery production costs and carbon emissions by up to 19.4% and 9.0%, respectively.

Finally, we will explore the implications of this research for the secondary battery industry and the need for manufacturers to reevaluate their current cathode material specifications.

post_title: Microsoft unbundles Office and Teams globally following years-long criticism
title: Microsoft removes Teams from Office 365 globally; new standalone pricing option available.
post_content:
In recent news, Microsoft has announced changes to its Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription services. The company has decided to exclude its business collaboration chat offering, Teams, from these services following scrutiny from the European Union regulator and complaints from rival Slack. This move is unlikely to change the commercial growth trajectory of Office 365, according to some analysts. Microsoft has also introduced a new standalone Teams offering for enterprise customers outside the EU and Switzerland.

The decision to remove Teams from the Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription services was made in response to concerns raised by the European Commission. Microsoft agreed to sell Office 365 suite sans Microsoft Teams offering in the EU and Switzerland last year. Microsoft has long allowed businesses to pay separately for Teams, but it has also offered the service bundled in the widely popular Office 365 suite.

Some competitors have accused Microsoft of using its market dominance to gain a competitive edge by leveraging Teams. Slack, owned by Salesforce, has termed Microsoft's actions "illegal" and alleged that the Windows-maker forced installation of Teams to customers through its market-dominant productivity suite and hid the true cost of the chat and video service.

Microsoft has not addressed these concerns in its blog post, but it has offered flexibility to its existing customers. Existing customers can choose to renew their current deal, update it or select a new offer that better suits their needs. For new customers, Microsoft has introduced standalone pricing for Teams at $5.25 per user per month. Additionally, Office packages without Teams will be available at prices ranging from $7.75 to $54.75, depending on the specific package and features included.

In a note seen by TechCrunch, Morgan Stanley analysts estimated that Microsoft's Monday decision is "unlikely to change the O365 commercial growth trajectory, as more consolidation (not less) seems to be the direction of travel for CIO's due to macro pressures and technological progress like GenAI driving stronger gains for the broader suites and deeper data sets." Additionally, providing more choice for purchasing Teams clearly illustrates its compelling value, at just $5.25 per user per month for New Microsoft Teams Enterprise (standalone), which compares to Slack Pro at $7.25/mo and Slack Business+ at $12.50/mo. The price reduction in the Enterprise Suites without Teams is only $2.25, yet the Standalone cost is $5.25. For new customers, this equates to a pricing increase. Using Teams in F1 SKU's costs only $0.50 per user per month and using Teams in Business SKU's cost only $1.25-$2.25 per user per month.

In conclusion, Microsoft's decision to remove Teams from its Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription services is unlikely to change the commercial growth trajectory of Office 365, as more consolidation seems to be the direction of travel for CIO's due to macro pressures and technological progress like GenAI driving stronger gains for the broader suites and deeper data sets. Providing more choice for purchasing Teams clearly illustrates its compelling value, and the pricing reduction in the Enterprise Suites without Teams is only $2.25, yet the Standalone cost is $5.25. For new customers, this equates to a pricing increase.

title: Powering the future: Advanced energy harvesting for IoT devices
post_content:
Energy is a crucial component of modern life, and the Internet of Things (IoT) is a prime example of how technology has made it possible to harness energy from various sources. However, the efficiency of electrostatic generators, which are used to power low-power devices in IoT networks, has been hindered by the high impedance mismatch between these generators and electronic devices. Researchers from Microsystems & Nanoengineering have developed a high-performance energy management unit (EMU) that addresses this challenge and significantly boosts the power efficiency of electrostatic generators for IoT devices.

Electrostatic generators have emerged as an appealing solution for powering IoT devices, as they can harvest energy from environmental sources such as wind and human motion. However, their effectiveness has been restricted by the high impedance mismatch when connected to electronic devices, leading to low energy utilization efficiency.

The EMU proposed in this study is designed to address the longstanding challenge of impedance mismatch and propel forward the potential for using environmental energy harvesting within the IoT domain. The research team has implemented an innovative EMU equipped with a spark-switch tube and buck converter. This breakthrough led to an unprecedented direct current output of 79.2 mW m-2 rps-1 in rotary electret generators, representing a significant leap in efficiency. Furthermore, the EMU increased the performance of contact-separated triboelectric nanogenerators by 50%, demonstrating its versatility across different energy-harvesting technologies.

The EMU's success stems from the meticulous optimization of critical components, such as the spark-switch tube and buck converter, which propelled direct current power generation to new heights. This progress not only surpasses existing energy efficiency benchmarks but also underscores the EMU's compatibility with a wide array of generator designs.

Zeyuan Cao, the co-author of the study, stated, "Our work represents a significant step towards the practical application of electrostatic generators in IoT devices. By optimizing our EMU, we've achieved unprecedented efficiency, making self-powered IoT devices more viable than ever."

This breakthrough not only enhances the efficiency and reliability of self-powered IoT devices but also facilitates their broader adoption in sustainable and remote applications. It heralds a new era of energy autonomy within the IoT landscape, marking a significant advancement in the realm of environmental energy harvesting for IoT applications.

In conclusion, the EMU developed by the research team is a game-changer in the world of IoT energy harvesting. Its innovative design and implementation have led to unprecedented power efficiency, making it a valuable asset for IoT devices. The potential of this technology is vast, and it is poised to revolutionize the way energy is generated and used in IoT applications.

post_title: GGV Capital is no more, as partners announce two separate brands
title: Venture Capital Firm GGV Capital Splits Operations into Two New Brands
post_content:
The VCs who once led GGV Capital, a 24-year-old cross-border firm that served as a bridge between the U.S. and China, have recently split their U.S. and Asia operations into two new brands.

Jenny Lee and Jixun Foo, veterans of the industry, have rebranded their Singapore-based operation as Granite Asia. Meanwhile, Hans Tung, a co-founder of the firm who resides in the Bay Area, has announced that the U.S. team will now be known as Notable Capital.

The decision to abandon the GGV Capital brand was based on the fact that both teams would be operating independently going forward, and they felt it was best to develop new brands.

Granite Asia, led by native Singaporeans Lee and Foo, will focus on startups in China, Japan, South Asia, Australia, and Southeast Asia. They are known for their successes, including the smartphone giant Xiaomi, the ride-hail giant Didi, and the delivery company Grab.

Notable Capital, on the other hand, will continue investing in the U.S., as well as in Europe and Latin America. The team is led by Taiwanese-American Tung, who has invested in known brands like Airbnb, StockX, and Slack. Other members of the team include Jeff Richards, who has backed Coinbase, Tile, and Handshake, and Glenn Solomon, who has invested in HashiCorp and Opendoor.

Oren Yunger remains on team Notable and was previously an investor at GGV Capital. Another longtime managing director at GGV Capital, Eric Xu, will continue to oversee the original firm's independently operated yuan-denominated funds.

GGV Capital raised $2.5 billion for its new funds in 2018, marking its largest family of funds ever. The investors have since split those assets under management, and Granite Asia is now managing a collective $5 billion altogether, while Notable Capital has roughly $4.2 billion.

In conclusion, the decision to split GGV Capital's U.S. and Asia operations into two new brands was based on the need for each team to develop its own brand. Both Granite Asia and Notable Capital have experienced success in their respective regions and have a strong track record of investing in successful startups. The split has allowed for more focused investment strategies, and it will be interesting to see how each team performs in the future.

Canoo, the German electric vehicle (EV) startup, released its fourth-quarter and full-year earnings for 2023 in a regulatory filing. ---------------------------

In 2023, Canoo generated $886,000 in revenue, which is a significant improvement from zero dollars in 2022. The company delivered 22 vehicles to entities like NASA and the state of Oklahoma, contributing to the increase in revenue. Additionally, Canoo reduced its loss from operations by nearly half, from $506 million in 2022 to $267 million in 2023. However, the revenue-to-losses gap is still considerable, with the company reporting total net losses of $302.6 million in 2023.

Canoo's Private Jet Usage
--------------------------

One of the most interesting aspects of Canoo's earnings report is the private jet usage of CEO Tony Aquila. Under a deal reached in November 2020, Canoo reimburses Aquila Family Ventures, an entity owned by the CEO, for use of an aircraft. In 2023, Canoo spent $1.7 million on this reimbursement, which is double the amount of revenue it generated. Canoo paid Aquila Family Ventures $1.3 million in 2022 and $1.8 million in 2021 for use of the aircraft.

Additionally, Canoo also paid Aquila Family Ventures $1.7 million in 2023, $1.1 million in 2022, and $500,000 in 2021 for shared services support in its Justin, Texas, corporate office facility, according to regulatory filings. These expenses add to the financial burden on the company, which is already struggling to keep up with its revenue targets.

Conclusion
----------

Canoo's earnings report highlights the gap between spending and revenue at the EV startup. Despite some progress on the expenses and revenue fronts, the company is still burning through cash and facing the risk of bankruptcy. In March 2020, Astra's Rocket 3.0 suffered a catastrophic explosion during prelaunch testing at Alaska's Pacific Spaceport Complex. The explosion was initially reported as an "anomaly," an industry term for any issue that deviates from the expected outcome. However, it was a clear indication of the rocket's failure.

At the time, Astra CEO Chris Kemp told TechCrunch that the rocket "suffered an anomaly following an otherwise successful day of testing in Kodiak in preparation for a launch this week." Meanwhile, Alaska Aerospace CEO Mark Lester told local reporters that the company was executing an emergency checklist and requested everyone to stay clear of the area. At the time of the failure, Astra was taking such failures in stride. The company believed that it could build rockets at such a high volume and at such a low price that some amount of failure could be priced in. Kemp summed it up in a May 2022 interview, saying, "The expectation I think that a lot of people have is every launch has to be perfect. I think what Astra has to do, really, is we have to have so many launches nobody thinks about it anymore."

Despite its initial success, Astra failed to materialize its plans, and after months of burning cash, the company's board quietly accepted a take-private deal from Kemp and CTO Adam London at a stock price of just $0.50 per share. The deal is expected to close sometime this quarter, and Astra will cease trading on the Nasdaq.

Astra did not return a request for comment on the 2020 launch failure. However, the video clip obtained by TechCrunch serves as a stark reminder of the dangers of space exploration and the importance of ensuring the reliability of rocket launches.

Astra had been one of the biggest success stories for space industry investors, with the startup going public in July 2021 at a $2.1 billion valuation after raising nearly $500 million for its ultra-low-cost launch plans. Astra's Rocket 3.0 suffered an explosive failure during prelaunch testing in March 2020. The video clip obtained by TechCrunch serves as a stark reminder of the dangers of space exploration. Despite initial success, Astra failed to materialize its plans, leaving a significant impact on the space industry. The take-private deal serves as a cautionary tale for other space startups.
